items.abstract:
<jats:sec><jats:title>Key content</jats:title><jats:p>
<jats:list list-type="bullet">

<jats:list-item><jats:p>Pregnant women should take 400 micrograms/day of folic acid periconceptionally.</jats:p></jats:list-item>

<jats:list-item><jats:p>High‐dose vitamins C and E are not recommended.</jats:p></jats:list-item>

<jats:list-item><jats:p>All pregnant women are now advised to take vitamin D supplements.</jats:p></jats:list-item>

<jats:list-item><jats:p>Less than 50% of pregnant women in the UK take the vitamins recommended for pregnancy.</jats:p></jats:list-item>

<jats:list-item><jats:p>Further collaborative research is required to understand the role of other vitamins in improving maternal and perinatal wellbeing in high and low‐resourced countries.</jats:p></jats:list-item>
</jats:list>
</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Learning objectives</jats:title><jats:p>
<jats:list list-type="bullet">

<jats:list-item><jats:p>To understand the role of vitamins in pregnancy.</jats:p></jats:list-item>

<jats:list-item><jats:p>To gain an overview of recommendations on vitamin supplementation in pregnancy.</jats:p></jats:list-item>

<jats:list-item><jats:p>To be aware of the benefits and harm of vitamin supplementation in pregnancy.</jats:p></jats:list-item>
</jats:list>
</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Ethical Issues</jats:title><jats:p>
<jats:list list-type="bullet">

<jats:list-item><jats:p>Is it appropriate to identify women at risk of vitamin deficiency based on parameters such as ethnicity and body mass index?</jats:p></jats:list-item>

<jats:list-item><jats:p>How should potential benefits and harms be balanced for mother and fetus when considering vitamin supplementation in pregnancy?</jats:p></jats:list-item>

<jats:list-item><jats:p>Is it ethical to consider food fortification with vitamins for the benefit of one group (pregnant women) when there may be harm for other groups (older persons)?</jats:p></jats:list-item>
</jats:list>
</jats:p></jats:sec>
title: Vitamin supplementation in pregnancy

short-container-title: Journal of the Royal Society of Health
items.abstract: <jats:p> THE AIM of the study was to investigate the extent and determinants of vitamin supplementation in early pregnancy. </jats:p><jats:p> Some 246 women were recruited in the antenatal clinics of a major teaching hospital and asked to com plete a brief questionnaire relating to sources of advice and details of diet and vitamin supplementation during the index pregnancy. Further information was abstracted from routine antenatal records. A total of fifty-seven women (23%) took some form of vitamin supplement during the index pregnancy. Factors which affected supplementation included advice received from diverse sources and whether or not the women took iron supplements. Somewhat surprisingly, supplementation was not affected by age, social class or reproductive history. </jats:p>
title: Vitamin Supplementation in Pregnancy

container-title: Journal of the Royal Society of Health

items.abstract: <jats:p>Ensuring that a woman is well-nourished, both before and during pregnancy, is crucial for the health of the woman and that of the unborn child.<jats:sup>1</jats:sup> Maternal deficiency in key nutrients has been linked to pre-eclampsia, restricted fetal growth, neural tube defects, skeletal deformity and low birth weight.<jats:sup>1,2</jats:sup> Many nutritional supplements containing vitamins, minerals and other micronutrients are heavily marketed to women for all stages of pregnancy. However, much of the evidence for vitamin supplementation in pregnancy comes from studies carried out in low-income countries,<jats:sup>3</jats:sup> where women are more likely to be undernourished or malnourished than within the UK population. The challenges lie in knowing which supplements are beneficial and in improving uptake among those at most need. Here we summarise current UK guidance for vitamin supplementation in pregnancy and review the evidence behind it.</jats:p>
title: Vitamin supplementation in pregnancy
